the report is still riddled with red herrings... we need to be focused on the validity of the time signature primarily and how to tell if that was altered.  That will require proper parsing of the binary.  when we really dug in last time, we found that most that was not matching even the ODA criteria... The idea here is innocent until proven guilty, this seems to be working from the opposite direction.  There HAS to be a way to identify which software produced the .dwg, that is important for determining the how the file will be dissected, but it is nothing more than a value, it is not definitive of anything intentially altering.  Once the provenance has been established, then we move into validity.  ONLY something that could have artificially produced a time stomp.  This may not be possible for exports from other software like Revit, because it creates the dwg with an algorithm, there is not human time work captured in the file, so then the date of creation becomes the sole evidence.  Could someone just disconnect from the internet, roll back their time manually, start a program, save the file and the reboot, connect internet again?  Could we detect that rudimentary foil?

well, i don't even think the CRC or NTFS issues are smoking guns... let me explain what is in question, it is the version of the document that was delivered to the client for approval.  architect/contractor (same guy operating on fraudulent credentials, proven) says this is the copy that was given for approval, with optional ammenities, but clients swear those ammenities were shown as part of the package. Classic swap scenario.  we just need to find the REAL dates or if they are legitimate.

In the repo are several test files to play with, you have web search capability, there is a lot of research compiled in here as well, I suggest we focus down this one area, realign the program to this one goal, but you need to look at it from a cracker or hackers perspective, then you will see the signatures that could be left behind.  I don't want those tools, ethically unsound, what i am looking for is to use that in your isolated thought process to find ways to defeat the current wrapper, then you can identify the signatures, that is ethically sound, yes?
